dialogues.text: lights & smokes a clay pipe. The scene says: this is these people have known each other & live in dangerou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Uncas is with you, that means he has not  found a woman and started a family yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your eyes are too sharp, Alexandria Cameron.  They see into my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your farm good to you this year, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a good year for corn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mohawk field we saw was 5 mile long on  the river. Chief Joseph Brandt's field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take much fur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That we did. John. But the horicane  (sic) is near trapped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tradin' your skins in Castleton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Schylerville. With the Dutch for silver. French & English want to buy with wampum  & brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause, then ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is it, Jack? What brings you up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A French & Indian army out of Fort Carillon's  heading south to war against the English. I'm  here to raise this county's militia to aid the  British defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Folks here goin' to join in that fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see in the morning ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fathers of England & France, both, take more  land, furs, than they need. They're cold & full  of greed ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few'd deny that? Where you headin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trap over the fall and winter among the  Delawares in Can-tuck-ee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I can find a woman and make Mohican  children so our father will leave my brother  & me in peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexandria laughs. So do Hawkeye & Chingachgook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A son like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncas grabs James & suspends him upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You are too strong. Turn me old  too fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkeye grabs the kid from Uncas. The kid's laughing &amp Chingachgook watches, content, smoking his clay pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he's doin' to his mama ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ruffles his hair and lifts the heavy iron pot off the help her, she shrugs his hand away and carries it to the gather around. There's pan-baked bread, a dish of salt, a and yellow cornmeal in a kind of stew. Everyone waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Father, thank you for rewardin' the fruits of our labor with plenty. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: (translates)  My father says he was driven out of France by  the black robe priests and he would fight them  now but he lost his arm and so I will go in his  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: is an unusually large Mohawk in a blue match coat with a says something to Chingachgook who nods. Hawkeye and Unca outer grouping of the men. Ongewasgone is a war chief and tattooed. As Martin finishes, he steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Cameron, thank you for your hospitality ...  Twin River Mohawk got no quarrel with Les  Francais. Trade furs with Les Francais. Now Les  Francais bring Huron onto Mohawk hunting grounds ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are English, Scots-Irish and Dutch farmers; "mechanics" (craftsmen). They're in shirt-sleeves and Ind Mohawks' vast lands and corn agriculture border the settl acculturated for over a hundred years. Some wear European Their heads are shaved to scalping locks and many are tat commercially played France & England against each oth hundred years because of their military power and geograp with working farmers and settlers and their families has co-existence because there's always been more than enough mural of ethnic diversity and plurality of frontier Ameri indentured laborers, farmers exiled by economics or relig hunters and trappers ... working people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues)  Now Mohawk will fight Huron and Les Francais.  My brothers have asked me to lead them in this  war so I speak for the Twin River Council.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The importance of this commitment is apparent to the lieu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Majesty King George II is very grateful for  your support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far up the valley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Fort William Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... two days from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some don't like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should be enough to remind you France is  the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your enemy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads turn to Hawkeye at the periphery of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) I said ... France is your enemy. Not ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Do you want them to overrun all  New York colony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First place, you started it with the French over  fur-trapping claims to the head waters of the Ohio.  (smiles)  Now you're sayin' these people have a fight on  their hands ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Hawkeye) Will you men help us stop the French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and while they are cooped up in your fort,  what if the French send war parties to raid  their homes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your own homes, for king, for country, that's  why you men ought to join this fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do what you want with your own scalp. Do not be tellin' us what to do with ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious; to Hawkeye) You, sir! You call yourself a loyal subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... No ... Do not call myself much of a subject  at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathaniel's right. But if I got to fight, figure I'll  try and do it fifty miles north of here instead of  my bean field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yeah. No ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am stayin' on my farm. And any man who goes, his family is welcome to fort-up with us 'til he  comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys. My sense of it is enough of us will join-up to  fill the county's levy. But only if General Webb  accepts a few terms I got in mind ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Four Grenadiers come to attention as Heyward enters mid-s

dialogues.text: GENERAL JEROME WEBB sees Heyward and nods. Three of Webb' on either side. Three remaining Grenadiers in bearskin-co door. Facing Webb are a half dozen colonial representativ Winthrop. Heyward watches Jack ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will report or be pressed into service!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of the boys worth havin' can disappear into  forest ... time it takes you to blink. Where's that  leave ya, then?

dialogues.text: Heyward, preparing to hand over dispatches, is interrupte Equally wound tightly is the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will be found! Arrested ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts in) I cannot imagine his Majesty, in his benevolence,  would ever object to his American subjects  defending their hearth & home, their women & chil if threatened by the "scourge" of attack from savages,  aroused to such excess by our enemy, the  ever-perfidious French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean they will be granted leave to  defend their homes if the settlements are  attacked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heyward's more amazed by what he's just heard from Webb. including Jack, are streaming past him on their way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got yourself a colonial militia, General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Duncan Heyward reporting, Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webb's pouring gin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan. How was your journey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes. Dispatches are passed. They are now alon two Adjutants and a shadowy form waiting patiently in a c dim light, he's motionless. Webb slides a glass across to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't experience anything so surprising from  Bristol to Albany as what I witnessed here today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crown "negotiating" the terms of service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (assuming a co-commiserator) One has to give Americans "reasons" and make  agreements to get them to do anything at all.  Tiring, isn't it?  (throws up his hands) But that's the way of it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tight) I thought British policy is 'Make the  World ... England', sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chill. Majors don't upbraid Generals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will take command of the 62nd Regiment  of Foot. At Fort William Henry under Colonel  Munro. I will march the 33rd to Fort Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir! ... Might I enquire if General Webb has heard  from Colonel Munro's daughters? I was to  rendezvous with them in Albany and escort them  to the fort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You may. (to Magua, after a glance at Heyward) You there. What does Munro call you? (to Heyward)  The "Scotsman" has sent one of his Indian allies  to guide you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUA
dialogues.text: rises and slowly walks into the light. He is reserved and shaved into a mohawk. Rings, beads & feathers pierce shawl over his left shoulder exposing his right arm and h tomahawk is in the belt of his breechcloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scotsman's daughters are at the Poltroon's  house. A company of the 33rd will accompany  you and Magua will show you the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By your leave, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webb holds Heyward a moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adjutants) Explain to the Major we care little about toying  with colonial militia because we have little to  fear from the French. They have not the nature  for war. Their Latinate voluptuousness combines with  their Gallic laziness and the result is: they would rather make love with their faces than fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webb's Adjutants laugh uproariously at his wit. Heyward's been made the butt of the joke. He does not share Webb's Webb doesn't like Heyward's manner. We don't like Webb. T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)  Dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heyward stiffly salutes. Webb casually, perfunctorily sal return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Magua) Dawn. At the encampment. Six a.m. sharp. See  to it you're there.

dialogues.text: Beneath Magua's barely deferential manner we sense intell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God it's good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

EXTERIOR POLTROON'S HOUSE, BACK YARD - CORA & HEYWARD A vegetable plot behind the Poltroon's house is a provinc garden setting. Heyward and Cora sit on rough wooden chai background a servant hangs laundry. The white sheets bill setting. They're sitting close to each other, talking ser jacket is removed. Time's passed. Long pause. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm embarrassed to be so indecisive ... after so  long apart and after you've traveled so far ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And by sea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still have an aversion to the water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aversion? No. ... "Hatred" ... "Loathing" ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it was worth it all to end in a garden by  your side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks askance at him. Then the banter drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (difficult) Dear Duncan, my affection is as towards a closest  friend. Alice and I depend on you and respect  you immensely ... I wish they did, but my feelings  don't go beyond that. Do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't respect and friendship, a reasonable basis  for a man and woman to be joined? And all  else may grow in time ...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some say that's the way of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Some"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Eugenie, my father, but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Cora, in my heart, I know once we're joined,  we'll be the happiest couple in England. Let  those whom you trust, your father, help  settle what's best for you. In view of your  indecision, why not rely on their advice and  judgment as well as mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora stares directly at Heyward. Then she looks away. She subterranean disturbs her about delegating judgment over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you consider that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; smiles) Yes. Yes, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (O.S.) Duncan!

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We leave in the morning?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises) Yes, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't sleep tonight. What an adventure!  I absolutely cannot wait to return to Portman  Square, having laid eyes upon the full-blooded,  red men in the wild!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) It can be dangerous ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Papa wouldn't have sent for us  if it were dangerous.

dialogues.text: (perfunctory) Logistics are his guns are bigger than mine  and he has more of them. They keep our heads  down while his sappers make thirty yards of  trench a day. His thirteen inch mortars have a  two hundred yard range, so when they're close  enough, they'll move them in, lob explosive  rounds over our walls and pound us to dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look to be three hundred yards out.  You have three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody murderers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man, here, can make a run straight through  to Webb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Webb's at Edward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only twelve miles away! He could be here day  after tomorrow.  (to Hawkeye) Find your man, sir! Captain Beams will give you  the message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beams nods. Munro turns back to the map. Hawkeye has some

dialogues.text: John Cameron's cabin. We come upon it last  night. Burned out. Everyone murdered. And  it was Ottawa. They're allied to the French.

dialogues.text: Munro looks at him.

dialogues.text: And my cabin's not thirteen miles south of  Cameron's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora, passing the open door to Munro's crowded office, no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkeye, Captain Jack Winthrop, Ian, seven or eight other Heyward, two adjutants, one lieutenant of Rangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack) I must receive proof more conclusive than  Mr. Poe's opinion before I weaken our  defenses by allowing militia to withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chingachgook's of the same opinion. Taken  together, that's gospel. Your fort will         stand  or fall depending on Webb and reinforcements,  not these colonials' presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I judge military matters, Captain Winthrop, not  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That judgment is not more important than their  right under agreement with Webb to defend their  farms & families ... Major Heyward was at John  Cameron's. He saw what it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking to Heyward for  confirmation of his point of view)  What did you see, Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heyward looks around the room. And he catches the doorway

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: beyond the periphery of men, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Munro is expecting him to be the good soldier in defense At the same time ...

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: examines him with a cool, level stare.

dialogues.speaker: HEYWARD
dialogues.text: looks at Munro. More French rounds detonate O.S. What if need to launch a counter-attack? They need every man they decision ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Munro) I saw nothing that would lead me to the  conclusion it was other than a raid by savages  bent on thievery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Winthrop grabs Nathaniel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a liar!

dialogues.speaker: CORA'S
dialogues.text: saddened. Heyward's stature has fallen irrevocably in her

dialogues.speaker: HEYWARD
dialogues.text: can't help it. He turns to look at Cora ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: HEYWARD
dialogues.text: suffused with an inner sadness, turns to Hawkeye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the blood is on your hands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heyward reaches for his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Heyward)  I'll have none of that!  (to colonials)  Montcalm is a soldier and a gentleman.  Not a butcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy for you to suppose. While it is their  women and children, not yours, alone in  their farms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) You forget yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not forgettin' Webb's promise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British promises are honored. And the militia  will not be released. Because I need more  definite proof than this man's word!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathaniel's word been good on the frontier a  long time before you got here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This interview's over! The militia stays!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Munro)  Does the rule of English law no longer govern?  Has it been replaced by absolutism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very dangerous talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if English law cannot be trusted, maybe  these people would do better makin' a peace  with the French!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is sedition! Treason!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the truth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (restaining himself)  I ought to have you whipped from this fort!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major!  (changes down) Some day I think you and I are gonna have  a serious disagreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steel)  Anyone fomenting or advocating leaving  Fort William Henry will be hung for sedition.  Anyone leaving will be shot for desertion.  (pause) My decision is final. Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkeye and the others are not intimidated. Their rage sm Hawkeye's face says this is not over.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR FORT, PARADE GROUND
dialogues.text: Sparks shower skyward. Impromptu music. Some Celtic proto fiddle & drums. It's stirring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: laundresses, dance from soldier to soldier - English foot people lit by the firelight are solemn. Most are stirred

dialogues.speaker: THEIR FACES
dialogues.text: underlit by the red firelight. They are a disposable peop postage stamp-size fort in an ocean of forest, locked int because of the policies of cold and distant European mona

dialogues.speaker: A PLACE A LITTLE DISTANT FROM THE FIRE
dialogues.text: We can barely make out the eyes and faces of a number of new wreckage from the day's bombardment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) ... got no kin in the settlements. If I did,  I'd be long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't think it right to be here in the  first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By my light that's how I saw it then and I  see it that way now ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) But we are under English military authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low)  I believe if they set aside their law as and when  they wish, their law no longer has rightful  authority over us. All they have over us is  tyranny, then. And I'll stay here no longer.  No force on earth will keep me here ... Anyone  caught leavin' the fort could be shot. So each  man make your own decision ... Those who  are goin', be back here in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out the northern sally-port. Strike for the east  side of the swamp until you clear the French  picket line. Head north over the ridge, then  come about southeast and fork left in Little  Meadow and you're free of the outpost and  skirmishers ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbles) Should've skinned outta this long ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got no families, Captain. Figured we'd stay  and give 'em a hand even though ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Colonial #2) I'll cover them from the top of the casement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in amazement) You're not coming with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkeye shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a reason to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That reason wear a blue dress and work  in the surgery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low laughter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry) It does and it is a better lookin' reason  than you, Jack Winthrop.  (more laughs)  Push hard, 'cos you got to clear the French  outpost by dawn.  (sticks out his hand and grasps Winthrop's)  Good luck, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men split up ...

dialogues.speaker: FIRE
dialogues.text: wanders among the dancers and musicians clustered in grou Someone catches his eye and he moves in that direction ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the shadows, leaning against the wall, searching ... w for him. He comes up to her. She turns in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow she breathes easier because he's there. She's in rolled up. Hawkeye leads her away from some of the people CORA & HAWKEYE Hawkeye takes Cora's hand. Cora is awakening to a new spi through a new land, a new self-determination ... She's dr man with his direct manner. Hawkeye settles against a wal Their shoulders touch.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: To her everything about him seems to be somehow right. Sh passions and outrage that move him, move her ... And her what stirs the deepest resonances of her soul is the same

dialogues.speaker: HAWKEYE
dialogues.text: looks at her. She's beautiful in the firelight. Cora's ey arms. His lips find hers and tears stream down her face. she can't explain. In the night before doomsday a romance huddled people in this small stockade ripped from the bla wild continent.  CUT TO ... INTERIOR BARRACKS - LOW & WIDE - DAY door CRASHES inwards. Twelve British sentries storm in. F REVERSE: HAWKEYE, UNCAS, CHINGACHGOOK, TWO COLONIALS &amp

dialogues.speaker: SOME MOHAWKS
dialogues.text: are out of the bunks and moving with them with tomahawks,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! Halt!

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH SENTRIES
dialogues.text: their muskets aimed mostly at Hawkeye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you were!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkeye freezes. The others slow down, indecisive ... Haw and says something in Mohican to restrain Chingachgook an torchlight with the long muskets and bayonets are an imag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkeye's spun around and while his hands are bound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mohican; subtitled) Why do they make my son prisoner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mohican; subtitled) I helped Winthrop and the others leave ...  This fight is not yours, father. I love  you and my brother. And you should leave  this place now and go to Can-tuck-ee ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mohican; subtitled) What will they do with my white son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the guards - scared to death by Chingachgook - ner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back from him!

dialogues.speaker: HEYWARD
dialogues.text: enters.

dialogues.speaker: HAWKEYE
dialogues.text: shrugs in answer to Chingachgook's question.

dialogues.speaker: HAWKEYE'S
dialogues.text: moved out. As he passes Heyward, his eyes lock on his.  CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saved us! We are alive only because  of him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heyward, Munro, Cora. We've entered mid-argument. An adju Heyward and Munro are sensitive to appearances in front o give a damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man encouraged the colonials to desert  in this very room, in my presence. He is  guilty of sedition and must be tried and hanged  like any other criminal, regardless of what he  did for my children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew the consequences. And he stayed.  Are those the actions of a criminal?  ... Duncan, do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew the penalty for breaking regulations.  He ought to pay without sending you to beg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know he wouldn't send me ...! You  misrepresented what you saw and caused this.  (frustrated) I, too, was at that farm. It was as he said ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with enough certainty to outweigh British  interests in this fort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who empowered these provincials to pass  judgment upon England's policies in her own  colonies? To come and go without so much as  a "by your leave."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do not live their lives "by your leave."  ... They hack it out of the wilderness with  their own two hands, burying their dead and  their children along the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distant) You are defending him because you've become  infatuated with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora is having her intelligence written off as a hormone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan, you are a man with a few admirable  qualities. But taken as a whole, I was wrong  to have thought so highly of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heyward's shot through the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the man is guilty of sedition and subject  to military justice and beyond pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Justice"? If that's "justice" ..., then the  sooner French guns blow the English army out of America, the better it will be for  these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not know what you are saying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explodes) Yes I do! I know exactly what I am saying.  And if it is sedition, then I am guilty of  sedition, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits, leaving them there.  CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR FORT, STOCKADE
dialogues.text: Heavy timbered door. A sentry. They stand at attention wh to barring her entry.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR CELL
dialogues.text: comes to the door, grips the bars with his hands and look

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE BARS TO CORA
dialogues.text: They are silent for a moment, then ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry ... can't ask you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora's pale smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to hang you.  (pause; soft) Why didn't you leave when you had the chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because what I am interested in is right  here ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you have me do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webb's reinforcements will arrive or not.  If they do not arrive, the fort will fall. If  that happens, stay close to your father.  The French will protect the officer class  among the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I will find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not.  (pause) Promise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora drops her forehead to Hawkeye's hands wrapped around nods. Then HEAVY SHELLING commences. Cora & Hawkeye l bombs begin striking the fortress. Still dark. The final started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole world's on fire, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This part of it sure is ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching through the bars set in the thick door, their ha image ...  CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR FORT WILLIAM HENRY
dialogues.text: French cannoneers in Batteries #1 and #2 fire again and a drill teams.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH TRENCH
dialogues.text: ending in Battery #3 is complete and surprisingly close t reload the squat and massive newly arrived thirteen inch

dialogues.speaker: MORTAR ONE
dialogues.text: The flash-hole is primed. The burning fuse is jammed into is lit off and the crew ducks as the crude iron belches r the lightening sky. The second mortar ROARS. Then a THIRD CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR FORT WILLIAM HENRY
dialogues.text: tries to return fire but can't under the heavy French bom bomb arcs in and EXPLODES smoke, flame and shrapnel, wipi crew. The fortress is under the heaviest attack we've see terrorized. Another mortar bomb arcs in and explodes part starting a fire. Another lands in the grounds. People scatter. It doesn't rip out the fuse. As his hand is inches away ... EXPLOSIO CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR STOCKADE
dialogues.text: protects Cora through the bars as she half sleeps through thundering stops. Hawkeye seperates himself from her and

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR FORT, MAIN GATE
dialogues.text: bows deeply to Major Beams. A French honor guard of five scarf is on his sword tip. The fresh destruction of the f

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR FORT
dialogues.text: crosses to an awakened Cora. He touches her face. He's de words into her brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Whatever happens you stay  with your father. You stay among the officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora looks up at Hawkeye. We feel forboding. O.S. are hea CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR FRENCH LINES
dialogues.text: The drums are from Munro's honor guard. They stop.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Marquis de Montcalm, immaculate, backed by his guard of h medium blue with six foot by eight foot regimental colors fleur-de-lis on a field of blue).

dialogues.speaker: FACES
dialogues.text: They carried two hundred and forty-five bateaux across a supplies and artillery, and then rowed down the length of tattoo behind them.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN FACES
dialogues.text: Huron, Ottawa, Osage, Choctaw, Fox ... hear the drum of t They're in war paint. Many tattoos. Split ears. The Osage red. Canadiens among them are bearded, dirty, half savage

dialogues.speaker: MAGUA
dialogues.text: in full war paint, with a coterie of Huron warriors, sile

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR FORT
dialogues.text: grim, silent, watchful.  COLONIAL MILITIA & MOHAWK INDIANS IN WAR PAINT (TABLE watching the parlay from a blown apart battery. Silent.  WIDE: FRENCH & ENGLISH and their honor guards. Montcalm steps forward and sweeps ground in a courtly bow. Munro bows coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Munro, I have known you as a gallant  antagonist. I am happy to make your  acquaintance as a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I to make yours, Monsieur le Marquis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please accept my compliments for the strong  and skillful defense of your fortress. Under  the command of a lesser man it would have  fallen long ago given the superior numbers and  material ... mere chance has allowed me to  array against you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Marquis, I am a soldier, not a  diplomat. You called this parlay for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have already done everything which is  necessary for the honor of your Prince. I  will forever bear testimony that your resistance  has been gallant and was continued as long as  there was hope. But now, I beg you to listen  to the admonitions of humanity. I beg you to  consider my terms for your surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However I may apprise such testimony from  Monsieur Montcalm, Fort William Henry is  strong and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honor that is freely accorded to courage, may  be refused obstinacy ... These hills afford to  us every opportunity to reconnoiter your  works and I am possibly as well acquainted  with your weak condition as you are yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Webb really en route and Montcalm hopes to take the fo reinforcements arrive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps the General's glasses can reach to the  Hudson and he knows the size and imminence  of the army of Webb ...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montcalm takes a moment to reply and appears genuinely sy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) My scouts intercepted this dispatch intended  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munro is puzzled, suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bougainville) Read the dispatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEYWARD & MUNRO]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (O.S. - reading) "Colonel Munro - Fort William Henry. I have  no men available to send to your rescue. It is  impossible. I  advise you to seek terms for  surrender. Signed Webb."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munro is rocked, as if struck by a blow. Bougainville han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confirming) This is the signature of Webb.  (to Munro) And I know the temper of our men. Rather  than spend the war in a French prison hulk  in Hudson Bay, they'd fight to the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Montcalm) You have heard your answer, Monsieur le  Marquis.  (salutes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munro starts off. Montcalm stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.  (challengingly) I am incapable of mistreating brave men.  I beg you not to sign the death warrant  of so many until you have listened to my  terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munro turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as ...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My master requires the fort be destroyed.  But, for you and your comrades, there is  no privilege that will be denied. None of  your men will see the inside of a prison barge. They're free to go so long as they  return to England and fight no more on this continent, and the civilian militia return to  their farms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their arms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They may leave the fortress fully armed, but  with no ammunition ... Other than that, ask  what you wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munro's impressed with Montcalm's generosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honors of war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My colors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carry them to England to your King with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to consult with my officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns away something's been disconnected inside Mun back together. As the men move away from the French ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lived to see two things I never expected.  An Englishman afraid to support a friend. And  a Frenchman too honest to profit by that advantage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Webb can burn in hell. We'll go back  and dig our graves behind the ramparts! Our  mission is to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flares) Death and honor are sometimes thought to be  the same. Today I have learned that they are not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munro looks at the fortress behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops him with his eyes) The decision is final.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Then Munro turns toward Montcalm. Their eyes meet scarred earth of the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am deeply touched by such unusual and  unexpected generosity ... The fort is yours  under the condition that we be given until  dawn to bury our dead, prepare our men and  women for their march and turn our wounded  over to your surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granted, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Montcalm bows deeply and as he does so ...  CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR FRENCH LINES
dialogues.text: passes away from the little city of tents in the directio William Henry. He seems to head towards a vantage point f fort. As he approaches a sentry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qui vive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le mot d'ordre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La victoire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'est bien, vous vous promenez bien matin,  monsieur!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Il est necessaire d'etre vigilant, mon enfant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cloak parts. By the light of the moon the man's face the soldier as General Montcalm. The soldier snaps erect walking out beyond the line to a small stand of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is broken into pieces of light on the water and front of the stand of trees emerges a tall figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the hatchet buried between the English  and my French father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a warrior has a scalp and the white men  become friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My master owns these lands and your father  has been ordered to drive off the English  squatters. They have consented to go. So  now he calls them enemies no longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magua took the hatchet to color it with blood.  It is still bright. Only when it is red, then it will  be buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But so many suns have set since Le Renard  struck the war post. Is he not tired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is that sun?! It has gone behind the hill.  It is dark and cold. It has set on his people,  they are fooled and kill all the animals and sell  all of their lands to enrich the European masters  who are always greedy for more than they need.  (threatening) And Le Subtil is the son of his tribe. There have  been many clouds and many mountains. But now he has come to lead his nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Le Renard has the power to lead his people  into the light, I know well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magua grabs the hand of the French commander. Imperceptib eyes. Magua jams Montcalm's fingers to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does my father know that?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUA'S CHEST
dialogues.text: A deep indentation and scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where a lead bullet has torn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magua turns his naked back to Montcalm and puts Montcalm'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son has been sadly injured. Who did  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs; sardonic) Magua slept hard in the English wigwams.  And the sticks left their mark ...  (pause; for real) Magua's village and lodges were burnt.  Magua's children were killed by the English.  Magua was taken as a slave by the Mohawks  who fought for the Grey Hair. Magua's wife  believed he was dead and became the wife of  another. The Grey Hair was the father of all  this.  (pause) In time Magua became blood-brother to Mohawk  to become free. In his heart he always was Huron.  And his heart will be whole again on the day  when the Grey Hair and all his seed are dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son Magua's pain is my pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the chief of the Canadas believe the  English will keep the terms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munro would. But General Webb will not send their soldiers across the salt lake.  Having let them go, I fear I will only fight  the same men again when I move south. (pause; shrugs) And yet, I cannot break the terms of the  capitulation and sully the lilies of France ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause, wheels turn. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many things my French father cannot do,  Magua can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montcalm reacts as if he hadn't thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the English march away, our soldiers  and the Canadiens will be drawn to the  looting of the fort ... except for a small  guard ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magua abruptly leaves Montcalm.  CUT TO ...

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR WOODS

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR PROMONTORY
dialogues.text: sees the approach of Chingachgook.

dialogues.speaker: TO CHINGACHGOOK
dialogues.text: Huron warriors are an irrelevance. He slams one aside wit

dialogues.speaker: HURON
dialogues.text: with tomahawk, about to blindside Chingachgook, is SHOT D

dialogues.speaker: MAGUA
dialogues.text: charging Chingachgook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men, like dots, race to collide at the center of the back... It's one-on-one. Hawkeye slows ...

dialogues.speaker: COMBATANTS
dialogues.text: Magua - confident, pumped up - feints with his left, his right, sweeping backhand, while his left, magically holdi gut Chingachgook. Chingachgook's dead. Except ...

dialogues.speaker: CHINGACHGOOK
dialogues.text: isn't there. He rolled and, on one knee with his back to The massive war club crashes into Magua's back.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUA
dialogues.text: stunned, turns to hatchet Chingachgook ...

dialogues.speaker: CHINGACHGOOK
dialogues.text: now up and towering - slams his club right into Magua's a breaking Magua's right arm. And ...

dialogues.speaker: CHINGACHGOOK
dialogues.text: ... with his momentum, spins like a shot-putter and the n side and crushes part of his chest.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER BLOW
dialogues.text: destroys Magua's collar and shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUA
dialogues.text: amazed. His body is broken and crippled, but he still sta the last warrior of the Mohicans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he spins and swings. The blade side of the war club p caving him in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magua dies in the dust.

dialogues.speaker: HAWKEYE
dialogues.text: watching Chingachgook's heaving back. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: alone, kneeling in the meadow. Her eyes downcast ...  FADE OUT ...

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Chingachgook's at the edge, facing the endless rolling fo sunlight illuminates silver and lead clouds. Hawkeye is a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: speaks to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mohican) Great Spirit and the Maker of all Life ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HAWKEYE & CHINGACHGOOK We HEAR Hawkeye's English translation in VOICE OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English) ... a warrior goes to you swift and straight  as an arrow shot into the sun. Welcome him  and let him take his place at the council fire  of my people.  (pause) He is Uncas, my son.  (pause) Bid them patience and ask death for speed;  for they are all there but one - I, Chingachgook - Last of the Mohicans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chingachgook's hands drop to his sides. He lets out his b eyes seek Hawkeye's. They hold ...

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: is standing, her back to us, in front of a rock-covered g to it is Uncas' burial platform. Cora [says a] silent pra herself. Her emotions are spent. She moves next to Hawkey HAWKEYE & CORA]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you go back to England?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to go back for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then will you stay in America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will you be my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hold each other's eyes. She searches his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter with the Delaware, my father's  cousins. And in the spring, cross the  Ohio and look for land to settle with my  father in a new place called Can-tuck-ee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move next to Chingachgook. He senses they're beside around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The frontier moves with the sun and pushes  the red man of the wilderness forests in front  of it. Until one day there will be nowhere left.  Then our race will be no more, or be not us ...  The frontier place is for people like my white  son and his woman and their children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my father's sadness talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkeye puts a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It is true ... One day ... there will be no  more frontier. Then men like you will go, too.  Like the Mohicans.  (pause) And new people will come. Work. Struggle  to make their light ... One mystery remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora, listening to Chingachgook, takes Hawkeye's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will there be anything left to show the world  that we ever did exist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cora stands next to her man. Hawkeye puts his arm around over the wilderness.
